thread.title_full: Rout in Kazakhstan’s currency may just be start of a monetary war - MarketWatch

author: Joseph Adinolfi
title: Rout in Kazakhstan’s currency may just be start of a monetary war
text:
Tremors from China’s devaluation of the yuan last week have forced a major monetary policy change in Kazakhstan.
Thursday morning, policy makers from the National Bank of Kazakhstan unhitched the country’s currency, the tenge, from a fixed exchange-rate against the dollar and almost instantly, the tenge shed 23% of its value.
It USDKZT, +0.00% recently traded at 252.53 tenge to the dollar — plunged 28% on the day.
Here’s a chart showing the dollar’s value spiking against the tenge:
FactSet Kazakhstan’s currency devaluation followed a similar, but less extreme, move by the State Bank of Vietnam on Wednesday.
And this is likely just the beginning of broader currency devaluations as emerging-markets economies that have tried to maintain stable exchange rates see pressure on their currencies intensify, currency strategists say.
Neil Shearing, chief emerging-markets economist at Capital Economics, said African countries like Nigeria and Kenya are particularly vulnerable as they’ve seen foreign-exchange reserves dwindle.
China’s devaluation could be the last straw for many of these economies, which have struggled with falling export prices. At the same time, rivals that allow their currencies to float more freely, like Russia, have seen their currencies depreciate, making their goods more competitive on the global market.
Exports of goods and services make up 40% of Kazakhstan’s gross domestic product, and its economy has already suffered from falling commodity prices. It’s particularly reliant on the export of crude oil, iron ore and industrial metals.
Russia and China are the two largest buyers of the countries imports. Kazakh companies have been struggling to compete against Russian firms that have a clear currency advantage. Now, they also will find it harder to compete against Chinese firms.
Gulf states like Saudi Arabia are also vulnerable because of the drop in oil prices, but they typically have much larger foreign-exchange reserves that can allow them to hold out for much longer, Shearing said.
Of course, the future path of commodity prices is a big unknown. For example, crude-oil futures for September delivery trading on the Nymex US:CLU5 hit a fresh six-and-half year low Wednesday.
A recovery in commodities could alleviate some — but not all — of the pressure on these economies.
But as long as crude-oil prices remain under siege, more countries may decide that the cost of managing their currency rates now outweighs the benefits.
